column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Use Car Ramps
#Text=Car ramps are an easy alternative to jack stands , as long as you use them correctly .
#Text=It may take a couple tries to drive up them if you have placed them on a smooth floor , but once up and centered , your car should be stable .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Choosing a Car Ramp
#Text=Check the maximum rated load .
#Text=This is the most important characteristic of your ramp : the larger this number , the safer you 'll be .
#Text=The ramp 's rating refers to the maximum Gross Vehicle Weight ( GVW ) that can be driven onto the ramp .
#Text=You can find the GVW on your driver 's door sticker or owner 's manual .
#Text=The ramp 's rating should be well above your car 's GVW , to allow for a margin of error or a front-heavy car .
#Text=This rating usually assumes you are using two ramps .
#Text=For example , a pair of ramps rated to 6,000 lbs can hold the front half of a 6,000 lb vehicle when using both ramps together .
#Text=Consider the country of manufacture .
#Text=Ramps made in the United States and the European Union are typically subject to stricter quality control than ramps from other countries .
#Text=While there are safe and well-made ramps manufactured elsewhere , you should use caution and find out what others think of the product before you take the risk .
#Text=Read reviews .
#Text=Some car owners tell horror stories of a ramp collapsing under much less than the rated load .
#Text=The risk is low but deadly , so it 's worth searching online for the opinions of other users .
#Text=Decide whether you need low-clearance ramps .
#Text=These ramps have a more gradual incline so a sports car can drive up them without scraping the undercarriage .
#Text=They tend to be expensive , so only buy them if you 're sure a regular ramp wo n't do .
#Text=Check for a rubber stop .
#Text=The underside of many ramps include a rubber component make it less likely the ramps will slide when the car starts to drive up them .
#Text=This is especially important if you work on your car on a smooth surface , since it will make it easier to drive up without the ramp sliding ahead of you .
#Text=Look for signs of damage .
#Text=Throw away the ramp if you see any obvious signs of rust , cracks , or other damage .
#Text=Purchase wheel chocks as well .
#Text=Using at least two wheel chocks is recommended whenever you have your car on ramps .
#Text=It 's hard to go wrong with chocks , but if you have a smooth or slippery garage floor , get soft rubber chocks .
#Text=Using the Ramps
#Text=Slide the ramps against the front tires .
#Text=Position the lower slope of a ramp so it is perfectly centered with the tire .
#Text=Sight along the side of the car to ensure the ramp is as straight as possible .
#Text=Repeat with a second ramp on the other side .
#Text=If the wheels are turned , move them so they point straight ahead and try again .
#Text=Always work on a hard , level , paved or concrete surface .
#Text=Avoid wet or slippery surfaces , which can make it difficult to drive up the ramp without sliding .
#Text=Drive up the exact center of the ramp .
#Text=Get in the car and drive forward directly up the ramp .
#Text=Get out and confirm that the front wheels are centered exactly on the ramps , and fully on the flat portion of the ramp .
#Text=If they are n't , drive back off and try again .
#Text=Most ramps have a small bump at the end to tell you when you 've reached the edge .
#Text=If this does n't look adequate on your ramp , have a friend spot you to prevent you from driving over it .
#Text=If the ramps slide forward as you drive , you 'll need to drive a little faster — but keep it smooth and cautious .
#Text=If you cannot safely drive up the ramp this way , hold the ramps in place by positioning a board between the wall and the back of the ramp .
#Text=Engage the parking brake .
#Text=Once you are sure the car is centered , use the emergency brake to ensure the car does not roll back down the ramp .
#Text=Stand to the side and gently rock the car to make sure it is stable .
#Text=Put two wheel chocks around a back wheel .
#Text=Place one wheel chock in front of the back wheel , and the other one behind .
#Text=This is an additional safety measure to keep the car from rolling in either direction .
#Text=Now you can safely access the underside of the car .
#Text=If you want to be extra safe , put your car on jack stands as well .
#Text=Video
#Text=Warnings
#Text=While under the car , never disassemble a part that could free the transmission or the brakes .
#Text=Do not try to make your own ramp at home .
#Text=They may look simple , but commercial ramps are much sturdier than what you can make at home .
